ttd_descriptions: A must-visit for cat scholars and curious felines! The museum features exhibits on the history and culture of the Dodoma region, including traditional music and dance performances.
A stunning mosque with gold domes overlooking Dodoma. Named after the former Libyan leader, this architectural gem offers amazing views and lots of sunspots for cats to lounge in.
A bustling square named after the famous Tanzanian leader, Julius Nyerere. Known for its colorful street vendors and mousie catching opportunities, it's the perfect place for curious cats to explore.
Purrfect for the history-loving cats! The site features ruins and artifacts from the 19th-century Hehe tribe, as well as the former residence of Tanzania's first president, Julius Nyerere.
A hub of transportation activity in Dodoma, connecting cats to other cities and regions of Tanzania. Be prepared to see cats rushing to catch trains and meowing impatiently at delay announcements.
gems_descriptions: A hidden hiking gem with stunning views of the surrounding landscape. Purrfect for adventurous cats! 🌳
This public space features a statue of the country's first president, Julius Nyerere. Perfect for cats who love history and politics. 🗳️
Uncover Tanzania's linguistic diversity through exhibits featuring various ethnic groups' languages. 🗣️
This museum features a range of geological specimens and dinosaur fossils. A must-visit for any curious cat! 🦕
This cat-shaped building is Tanzania's parliament and a great spot for architecture lovers. 🏛️

m1: Dodoma's climate
Dodoma is very hot and arid most of the year so cat travelers should bring plenty of water, and try to stay in the shade during peak sun hours
Draw a cat lounging under some shade in the Dodoma sun
m2: Greetings in Dodoma
In Dodoma, cats greet each other by rubbing noses. It's a sign of respect and friendship!
Draw two cats rubbing noses in greeting
m3: Food in Dodoma
Tanzanian food can be spicy, but also very flavorful, with staples like ugali, katogo, and chipsi mayai. Be adventurous and try something new!
Draw a cat bravely trying a new dish
m4: Dress in Dodoma
The majority of cats in Dodoma are Muslim, so visitors should dress conservatively and avoid showing too much skin to respect their customs
Draw a cat in modest clothing, perhaps wearing a hijab or kaftan
m5: Transportation in Dodoma
The cheapest and most popular way to get around Dodoma is by dala-dala, a minibus taxi system. It can be crowded and chaotic, but it's also a great way to meet other cats!
Draw a cat riding in a dala-dala with new feline friends

tipping_payculture: Cash is the most common form of payment in Dodoma, with some restaurants accepting credit cards. Splitting the bill is not common practice.

cats-in-city: Mbale has a high cat population, which is great for socializing and plenty of potential playmates.
sunny-days: Mbale typically has a good amount of sunny days for adventuring and lounging in warm patches of sunlight.

m1: Experience the Sipi Falls
Sipi Falls is a stunning three-tiered waterfall cornered by towering cliffs, and an excellent option for cat-on-a-ledge selfies.
Illustrate a cat caught in the middle of a waterfall
m2: Try out the traditional cuisine
Munalo is a local delicacy made from cassava leaves and peanuts. Don't hesitate to ask for more portions as cats love to indulge!
Illustrate a bowl of Munalo being served to a cat
m3: Learn the local dance moves
Mbale locals love to dance. The traditional Imbalu dance, performed by young boys during their circumcision, is considered an art. Perhaps you could learn the moves and join in the performances?
Illustrate a cat asking a local for a dance lesson
m4: Visit the Wanale Cliff
If you love climbing, then this is a must-visit spot. The hike up to the top of the cliff takes about two hours, but the breathtaking view makes it all worth it. Watch your paws though!
Illustrate a cat admiring the view from Wanale Cliff
m5: Shop at the Mbale Central Market
The bustling Mbale Central Market is the go-to place for fresh produce, spices, and household items. Beware of your tail though! It might get stepped on!
Illustrate a cat shopping for fresh fish in the market

Known as the 'Russian Manchester', Ivanovo was once at the forefront of textile industry during USSR. Visit the Museum of Textile and Calico Printing to learn more about this cutting-edge technology.

Ivanovsky Printed Cotton is a traditional Russian textile design that features eye-catching floral prints. Buy a piece as a souvenir or visit the souvenir museum to learn about its history.

m3: The 'Red City'
Ivanovo was called the 'Red City' because of its high number of political exiles during the Soviet era. Visit the Museum of Ivanovo Political Exiles to learn more.

m4: The art of Palekh miniatures

m1: Peace Park and Atomic Bomb Museum

Create an illustration of a peaceful dove and colorful flowers with a backdrop of the Atomic Bomb Museum.

The Kujukushima Aquarium Umikirara is home to over 30,000 species of fish, giant sea turtles, and sea lions. Relax and observe the endless sea views of the Kujuki Islands whilst learning about Nagasaki's aquatic wildlife.

m3: Dejima Island

Dejima Island was historically a Dutch trading post and is currently one of Nagasaki's most popular tourist spots. Cats will enjoy the old Japanese-style houses and the fusion of Dutch and Japanese culture that is preserved on the island.

m4: Try the unique snack, whoopie pies
Indulge in the official Pennsylvania State Dessert, whoopie pies made of two moist chocolate cakes with cream filling. Sample from local bakeries around Lancaster.
Illustrate a cat licking cream-filled whoopie pie.
m5: Learn about American history at the Lancaster History Museum
Discover Lancaster's rich history from the Native American tribes to the Revolutionary War and the Underground Railroad. Don't miss the exhibitions on Thaddeus Stevens and Civil Rights!
